title: Is there any diagnostic software, that can fix all my computer problems? - Quora

response.answer_text: The short answer is NO. The long answer is, there are some wonderful tools, and each of them fixes different things. Some things are unfixable ( hardware errors, rom corruptions, eprom failures - you’re going to be digging into the computer and replacing parts, if you know how) Other things require multiple steps, like reformatting the hard drive, reinstalling programs, updating drivers,etc. The “fixable” problems will fall into several distinct categories: Virus, malware and the like.Storage messiness ( Windows is somewhat like a child who never fully cleans up their room….)Driver software issuesOperating system failures, due to corruption of the code by hard disk error, random stuff.Evil voodoo weird, unaccountable stuff, for which there is no known rational explanation, but which does happen.There are wonderful tools to help you, if you have certain problems. But those tools are operating system family specific. Windows tools and Apple tools. If you are using Linux, there are specialized tools for it too. For Windows, I am going to recommend a few neat programs: Malwarebytes, Ccleaner, …. see this article: The Best PC System Utilities and Repair Software of 2019 For Apple: Malwarebytes, CleanMyMac, … see this article: Best apps to keep your Mac fast and clutter free

First, what are your computer problems. If your computer is slow, you might wanna try this: CCleaner Official Site | Clean & speed up your PC | Piriform If you have viruses/malware, there’s tons of them. Here’s something you might find useful: The Best Antivirus Protection for 2019If you’re using Windows, Microsoft’s own security solution called Security Essentials is also pretty decent. Most of the antivirus software does offer a firewall protection. Still, take a look here for firewall suggestions: Best firewall of 2018 For VPNs you might wanna take a look here: These are your best, most secure VPN optionsKeep in mind, that browsers such as Brave and Opera do have built-in VPNs and adblockers. Speaking of adblockers I use AdBlock Plus, and I’m pretty happy with it. It’s available for Chrome, Firefox, Opera and Safari
